values.description: Based on the initial work of @scpeters and some discussion with the ROS team, this is a rough design document outlining how we should change SDF to support generic `<param>` elements. It is motivated by the current process of adding new parameters to the physics engines, which is a time-consuming process that might not be scalable.
values.title: Generic physics parameters in Gazebo and SDF

summary.raw: Based on the initial work of @scpeters and some discussion with the ROS team, this is a rough design document outlining how we should change SDF to support generic `<param>` elements. It is motivated by the current process of adding new parameters to the physics engines, which is a time-consuming process that might not be scalable.
summary.html: Based on the initial work of @scpeters and some discussion with the ROS team, this is a rough design document outlining how we should change SDF to support generic <param> elements. It is motivated by the current process of adding new parameters to the physics engines, which is a time-consuming process that might not be scalable.

values.title: RoboCup 3D Soccer Simulation

summary.html:
This document describes the overall architecture and development process for a Gazebo plugin which works as a server for the RoboCup 3D Soccer Simulation League.

There is a partial implementation here which uses ROS, but @caguero and I thought of making a new implementation based purely on Gazebo to decrease complexity. A great part of what's already been done can be ported to a plugin.

#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/05b163827042b70ecc8c29a1fe7fbfe05cda17df/robocup3ds/robocup3ds.md?at=robocup3ds

values.description: The overall goal for this work is to enable users to create an assembly of models. As opposed to using the `<include>` element which just copies the links from one model to another and prefixes the link names with a namespace, the new approach simply allows one to embed a `<model>` element inside another.
values.title: Add support for nested models in Gazebo

summary.raw: The overall goal for this work is to enable users to create an assembly of models. As opposed to using the `<include>` element which just copies the links from one model to another and prefixes the link names with a namespace, the new approach simply allows one to embed a `<model>` element inside another.
summary.html: The overall goal for this work is to enable users to create an assembly of models. As opposed to using the <include> element which just copies the links from one model to another and prefixes the link names with a namespace, the new approach simply allows one to embed a <model> element inside another.

values.description:
I have created these design documents in response to the meeting at the OSRF on June 22, 2015. 

This pull request introduces the following new ideas:

1. A new altimeter sensor that makes use of the generic noise model architecture
1. A new magnetometer sensor that make use of generic noise model architecture
1. An update to the IMU sensor that moves it to the generic noise architecture
1. A proposal to add clock noise, which would optionally perturb sensor measurement timestamps to mimic  the effect of clocks that drift with respect to each other.
1. A modification to the NoiseFactory class to take a reference to a sensor, with the goal of giving noise models the ability to measure pose/twist/time. 
1. The introduction of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck time-correlated noise model
1. The introduction of an Wiener time-correlated noise model
values.title: Improve sensor noise models

summary.raw:
I have created these design documents in response to the meeting at the OSRF on June 22, 2015. 

This pull request introduces the following new ideas:

1. A new altimeter sensor that makes use of the generic noise model architecture
1. A new magnetometer sensor that make use of generic noise model architecture
1. An update to the IMU sensor that moves it to the generic noise architecture
1. A proposal to add clock noise, which would optionally perturb sensor measurement timestamps to mimic  the effect of clocks that drift with respect to each other.
1. A modification to the NoiseFactory class to take a reference to a sensor, with the goal of giving noise models the ability to measure pose/twist/time. 
1. The introduction of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck time-correlated noise model
1. The introduction of an Wiener time-correlated noise model
summary.html:
I have created these design documents in response to the meeting at the OSRF on June 22, 2015.

This pull request introduces the following new ideas:

  1. A new altimeter sensor that makes use of the generic noise model architecture
  2. A new magnetometer sensor that make use of generic noise model architecture
  3. An update to the IMU sensor that moves it to the generic noise architecture
  4. A proposal to add clock noise, which would optionally perturb sensor measurement timestamps to mimic the effect of clocks that drift with respect to each other.
  5. A modification to the NoiseFactory class to take a reference to a sensor, with the goal of giving noise models the ability to measure pose/twist/time.
  6. The introduction of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck time-correlated noise model
  7. The introduction of an Wiener time-correlated noise model

values.description: This document outlines the proposed design changes for replacing the direct calls to Ogre with a generic interface. The main goal is to allow other render-engines to be easily used in place of or in tandem with Ogre.
values.title: Abstracting Render-engine Interface in Gazebo

summary.raw: This document outlines the proposed design changes for replacing the direct calls to Ogre with a generic interface. The main goal is to allow other render-engines to be easily used in place of or in tandem with Ogre.
summary.html: This document outlines the proposed design changes for replacing the direct calls to Ogre with a generic interface. The main goal is to allow other render-engines to be easily used in place of or in tandem with Ogre.

values.description:
This is a draft of the design for a simulation validation tool for Gazebo.

We would like to have this tool stable and ready to be used by October so it can collect data for a HAPTIX milestone in November.

values.description:
Pull request #24 was declined because the proposed "local undo" approach wouldn't be very useful during simulation.

This new design proposes a more global approach managed by the server instead of the client.

See the pretty file:

summary.html:

This new design proposes a more global approach managed by the server instead of the client.

values.description:
Document describing a strategy for graphically modifying inertia, an extension of our inertia visualization. I mainly propose tests for the server, to verify that inertia modifications are made correctly. I briefly describe the GUI features but could use some advice on which types of GUI tests to propose.

* #!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/inertia_resize/inertia_resize/inertia_resize.md

I've already started adding tests for the server in [gazebo branch inertia_msgs](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/commits/branch/inertia_msgs).
values.title: Graphically modifying inertia

values.description: While trying to examine the object lifecycle and ownership patterns in gazebo, I realized that I didn't understand the `gazebo::event` classes used for generating callback functions in response to triggered events. So I studied it for a while and wrote this document based on my current understanding. I've also noticed a few things that could be changed, which are noted and may lead to gazebo pull requests.
values.title: Document design of gazebo::event callback classes

summary.raw: While trying to examine the object lifecycle and ownership patterns in gazebo, I realized that I didn't understand the `gazebo::event` classes used for generating callback functions in response to triggered events. So I studied it for a while and wrote this document based on my current understanding. I've also noticed a few things that could be changed, which are noted and may lead to gazebo pull requests.
summary.html: While trying to examine the object lifecycle and ownership patterns in gazebo, I realized that I didn't understand the gazebo::event classes used for generating callback functions in response to triggered events. So I studied it for a while and wrote this document based on my current understanding. I've also noticed a few things that could be changed, which are noted and may lead to gazebo pull requests.
